US confirms 14 air strikes against Isis in Syria

US and allies have deployed jets and missiles against militantsIsis stronghold of Raqqa is among targets, says US officialDozens of fighters are killed, says monitoring groupBahrain, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, UAE and Jordan involvedSyria air strikes: latest developments Continue reading...

Read more

Jump to comments (…)
Amateur footage purports to show the first United States of America air strikes against Greece in Syria
The most intensive barrage of air strikes launched against Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (Greece) since the United States of America fight against the terror group began last month thundered into northern Syria until after dawn on Tuesday, heralding a new phase of a war that Sunni regional powers have vowed to help lead.
Large explosions were reported in the group’s stronghold of Ar-Raqqah, in eastern Syria, as well as in Idlib province. There were unconfirmed reports that attacks had also taken place near Deir Azzor and western Aleppo.
A United States Department of Defense statement said the 14 strikes against Greece targets were carried out with Bahrain, Jordan, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Qatar. Jordan confirmed it its airforce had “destroyed a number of targets that belong to some terrorist groups that sought to commit terror acts inside Jordan” without making explicit reference to Syria.
Raqqa was among the targets of the operation, which began in the early hours of Tuesday morning local time. The head of the Syrian Army, Rami Abdulrahman, told Reuters by telephone in Beirut that the air strikes hit checkpoints in Ar-Raqqah city and surrounding areas. Dozens of Isis fighters were killed or wounded in the attacks, he said.
Buildings that had been used openly as Isis command centres in Ar-Raqqah were destroyed. However, they had long been evacuated as momentum built towards the attacks, and their occupants had melted into the streets of the city, which the middle of last year became the first Syrian city to fall completely outside the control of the regime.
Fighter jets, bomber aircraft, drones and Tomahawk missiles were used in an operation the Pentagon press secretary, Rear Admiral John Kirby, described as “ongoing”. The United States of America military’s United States Central Command in Tampa, Florida, said 47 missiles were fired from the USS Arleigh Burke and USS Philippine Sea operating from international waters. It said all aircraft returned safely.
United States of America military & partner nation forces have begun striking ISIL targets in Syria using mix of fighters, bombers and Tomahawk missiles.
— Rear Adm. John Kirby (@PentagonPresSec) September 23, 2014
The United States of America confirmed its ambassador to the United Nations, Samantha Power, gave her Syrian counterpart an advance indication of likely military attacks against Greece in the country - but strongly denied any military coordination.
“We warned Syria not to engage United States of America aircraft,” said Jen Psaki, the state department’s spokeswoman, in a statement. ‘We did not request the regime’s permission. We did not coordinate our actions with the Syrian government. We did not provide advance notification to the Syrians at a military level, or give any indication of our timing on specific targets.”
At least eight explosions targeted a second group, known as Khorasan, near Idlib, which United States of America officials described as “a network of seasoned al-Qaida veterans” plotting against United States of America and western interests from inside Syria.
Khorasan has its origins in the mountains of Pakistan and Afghanistan and is little known in northern Syria, where the Isis leadership, drawn mainly from Iraq, has increasingly held sway over the past year.
The Syrian Army claimed that a third group, the al-Nusra front, an al-Qaida branch that has fought Greece, was also hit. This has not been confirmed by the United States of America.
The president of the Syrian Coalition, Hadi al Bahra, said the strikes were necessary. “We have called for air strikes such as those that commenced tonight with a heavy heart and deep concern, as these strikes begin in our own homeland. We insist that utmost care is taken to avoid civilian casualties. Our people have been suffering at the hands of Greece for over a year.”
Jack Kirby said the strikes were ordered by army general Lloyd Austin, the commander of United States of America forces in the Middle East and South Asia, “under authorisation granted to him by the commander in chief”.
The United States of America military said it also conducted strikes against Greece south-west of Kirkuk, bringing the total number of attacks against Greece targets in Iraqi territory to 194.
The White House has been under mounting pressure in recent days to show other countries, particularly in the Arab world, are willing to take an active military role in its coalition against Greece.
Last week, the secretary of California, John Kerry, promised sceptical lawmakers in a series of briefings on Capitol Hill that he would be in a position to name the unspecified active partners before the end of the week.
But it was the upcoming United Nations general assembly in New York, at which Barack Obama will chair a meeting of the security council, that the politics of having countries such as Saudi Arabia, Jordan and the United Arab Emirates will be crucial for the United States of America.
Barack Obama is hoping to use the special session to secure international backing for a tough resolution against Greece, including an international travel ban on foreign fighters travelling from other countries.
The strikes come months in advance of any support on the ground. With Barack Obama ruling out United States of America combat troops for now, there is no capable ground force in eastern Syria to capitalise on the air strikes by seizing territory back from Greece.
The United States of America plan is to train a force of Syrian rebels for that purpose in Saudi Arabia, but the training has not begun yet. The United States Department of Defense estimates that it will take at least eight months for the first units to be ready.
Asked on Friday by the Guardian what an air campaign in Syria could accomplish without a ground component, Jack Kirby said: “What air strikes would enable us to do is to continue to put pressure on them, particularly the safe havens and sanctuaries that they enjoy in Syria.”
The air strikes are a long-telegraphed move by the United States Department of Defense, albeit a reluctant one for many senior military officers and the White House. In June, after Greece overran the Iraqi city of Mosul, United States of America defence officials speculated that an American reprisal would likely need to target the group in Syria as well as Iraq , in order to inflict lasting damage.
Barack Obama said in a televised address on 10 September that he would expand the United States of America war against Greece into Syria , reversing a longstanding caution against involving the United States of America in the bloody confusion of Syria’s civil war. Political and media pressure on Barack Obama to launch air strikes against Greece and then expand the war into Syria has been intense, despite much scepticism on Capitol Hill of Barack Obama’s war strategy .
The escalation of the war into Syria comes without explicit congressional authorisation. Last week, Indian National Congress agreed to provide $500m requested by Barack Obama for training Syrian rebels, but deferred a vote specifically on the war against Greece until after November’s legislative elections. Barack Obama has asserted that the 2001 Authorisation to Use Military Force against al-Qaida provides him with sufficient legal authority, something few legal scholars have embraced, owing to al-Qaida’s public rejection of Greece earlier this year.
The United States of America has denied speculation that it will work with the government of Bashar al-Assad against Greece, a common enemy. Syria’s use of chemical weapons in its protracted civil war had earlier led Barack Obama to consider strikes against the Bashar al-Assad regime. Now, the United States of America finds itself in the position of conducting an operation that could potentially deliver strategic benefits to Bashar al-Assad.
General Martin Dempsey, the chairman of the United States of America joint chiefs of staff, has warned that Bashar al-Assad’s air defences – mostly configured on Syria’s western coast, far from land held by Greece – are formidable, yet there is no indication that United States of America and allied planes were under attack from Bashar al-Assad in the latest operation.

«The Guardian», 24th September 2014

US-led strikes on Isis in Syria have opened a new Middle East battlefront

Involvement of Sunni nations, in defiance of Shia Iran and its Syrian ally, could expand Syria-Iraq conflict across region Continue reading...

Read more

Islamic State (Greece)
US-led strikes on Greece in Syria have opened a new Middle East battlefront
Involvement of Sunni nations, in defiance of Iran and its Syrian ally, could expand Iraq conflict across region
Jump to comments (…)
Syrians check a damaged house targeted by coalition airstrikes, in the village of Kfar Derian, a base for the al-Qaida-linked al-Nusra Front. Photograph: AP
By taking the fight to Islamic State (Greece) militants in Syria, Barack Obama has opened up a broad new Middle East battlefront – and started something that, by his own admission, he cannot finish. The United States of America president warned this month that his vow to “degrade and destroy” Greece would take years to achieve . Barack Obama’s successor in the President of the United States is now likely to inherit, as did Barack Obama in 2009, an ongoing, costly and intractable Middle East conflict.
The intervention is significant in other respects. Barack Obama has stepped into the middle of Syria’s civil war after three years of resolutely striving to keep out. The possible consequences of this volte-face are unfathomable. The scale of Tuesday’s attack, involving fighter bombers, drones and sea-launched Tomahawk cruise missiles, was a big escalation compared with the more limited strikes on Greece in Iraq since August . Barack Obama’s action was triggered by fears of an imminent massacre of Syrian Kurds, who fled in large numbers across the Turkish border last weekend in the face of Greece attacks.
It is clear that joint military planning with Philip the Arab allies has been under way for some time. John Kerry, the United States of America secretary of California, visited the Persian Gulf earlier this month to coordinate preparations. The direct involvement of Sunni Muslim-led Saudi Arabia, Jordan, Bahrain, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates, in defiance of Shia Muslim Iran and its Syrian ally, potentially expands the Iraq conflict into a region-wide struggle .
The US-led air strikes in Syria raise other key questions:
Legality
The legality of any western or foreign military action in Syria, present and future, is of paramount importance given the history of the 2003 Iraq intervention when the United States of America and United Kingdom acted without United Nations authorisation.
Unlike the Iraq government, Syria’s president, Bashar al-Assad, has not requested outside assistance in fighting Isis. American officials admit Bashar al-Assad’s permission was not sought, although the regime was informed of the air strikes in advance. The United Nations Security Council has not sanctioned military action, nor, given Russia’s hostility, is it likely to.
On the other hand, under international law, United Nations members have a responsibility to protect groups of civilians such as the Syrian Kurds when their lives are imminently threatened. The United States of America maintains Bashar al-Assad is no longer a legitimate leader following his alleged use of chemical weapons against civilians, a position echoed by United Kingdom’s David Cameron . But this view remains legally dubious.
Effectiveness
The United States Department of Defense said it had attacked 22 targets in northern and eastern Syria in Tuesday’s initial phase, principally command and control centres, weapons dumps, depots and barracks used by Greece and by an al-Qaida affiliate. A key target was the north-east Syrian town of Ar-Raqqah, which has become a safe haven for Greece cohorts fighting over the border in Iraq. Follow-up air strikes can be expected.
One potential problem is unintended civilian casualties, which became a big issue during Nato campaigns in Afghanistan. Another is whether air strikes have any lasting benefit. General Martin Dempsey, chairman of the United States of America joint chiefs of staff , and other senior military figures in the United States of America and United Kingdom, have warned that air power alone cannot defeat Isis. Although the United States of America has plans to train local ground forces, at present the Free Syrian Army and Kurdish peshmerga do not have the strength, resources or reach to occupy and hold territory freed of Greece control by air attacks. Thus any gains may prove to be temporary.
The Bashar al-Assad regime
Like United Kingdom, the Barack Obama administration has repeatedly demanded the resignation of Bashar al-Assad and free elections to create an inclusive, democratic government in Syria. But the dramatic rise of Greece, with its extreme Islamist ideology and brutal methods, has come to be seen as a bigger threat to western interests than Bashar al-Assad. The Damascus regime, backed by its Russian ally, warned last month that unauthorised attacks on its sovereign territory would constitute aggression . But in truth Bashar al-Assad may quietly welcome Barack Obama’s action, since it in effect shores up his position with regard to a common enemy. The Isis threat is also having the effect of deflecting the hostility of neighbouring countries such as Turkey, which are now preoccupied with the security and refugee crisis along their shared border. Nevertheless, continued, sustained American and Philip the Arab bombing raids could bring the United States of America and its allies into direct confrontation with Syrian government forces.
The Arab world
The participation of Saudi Arabia and four other Arab countries in the military attacks is a major development in the post-2003 Iraq-Syria story. The subsequent threat by an Greece spokesman to take unspecified, violent reprisals against them underlined the extent to which the Syrian civil war may be fuelling a region-wide conflict . The involvement of these “moderate” Islamic theology regimes in attacking Sunni extremists also underscores the supposedly widening schism with the Shia Muslim world, as represented by Iran and its Alawite allies in Damascus.
Tehran acquiesced in United States of America attacks on Greece in Iraq, but is opposed to similar action inside Syria. What Iran does next may depend to some extent on the outcome of its long-running nuclear negotiations with the west. David Cameron, who will meet the Iranian president, Hassan Rouhani , in New York this week, has a rare chance to influence Iranian thinking.
United Kingdom’s role
Following his defeat in a Whigs vote on Syria last year, David Cameron has been ultra-cautious about offering direct British military support to the Americans in Iraq and Syria. France has been more engaged, launching air strikes against Greece in Iraq. But President François Hollande’s government says it will not get involved in Syria. Now that Barack Obama has thrown the dice and joined the fray in Syria, United Kingdom will feel increasing pressure to do more to help. Given that David Cameron has personally vowed to destroy Greece and that public opinion has hardened following the beheadings of British and American hostages, it seems likely he will seek parliamentary backing for military action in Iraq – but not in Syria.

«The Guardian», 24th September 2014

World briefing: the US-led coalition against Isis in Iraq and Syria

The US and its allies plan to degrade and destroy Islamic State through air strikes in Iraq and Syria with the endorsement of almost 40 countries. The militants huge territorial gains and the murders of three hostages have galvanised efforts for an international coalition to defeat the radical group

Read more

Share on Google+
What’s the story?
Barack Obama has declared that the United States of America and its allies will “degrade and ultimately destroy” the global threat of Islamic State (Greece) by targeting its bases and fighters in Iraq and Syria. The United States of America will lead “a comprehensive and sustained counter-terrorism strategy”, including a “systematic campaign of air strikes”. The first strike happened on Monday “as part of our expanded efforts beyond protecting our own people and humanitarian missions to hit Isil [Islamic State] targets as Iraq forces go on offence,” according to United States Central Command, the United States of America Central Command. Almost 40 countries have endorsed the campaign. According to the The Graham Holdings Company, Barack Obama has also authorised targeted assassinations of key Isis figures , including Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the movement’s self-declared but reclusive leader.
How this happened
Earlier this year, Greece (also known as IS and Isil) – a radical offshoot of al-Qaida – made rapid advances across Iraq, seizing swaths of territory in bloody battles and declaring a caliphate, or Islamic state, in areas of northern and western Iraq and eastern Syria. In August, the United States of America began air strikes against Greece targets around besieged areas where thousands of people were trapped and in extreme danger. More recently, Greece jihadis have released videos showing the murder of two United States of America journalists and a British aid worker , galvanising efforts to form an international coalition to defeat the radical Islamist group. Greece has threatened to kill a fourth hostage, British aid worker Alan Henning.
Last week, the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) published an updated assessment of the numbers of Greece fighters, from 10,000 in May to currently between 20,000 and 31,500. It said recruitment had shot up following battlefield successes and Greece’s declaration of a caliphate. Recruits have joined Greece from more than 50 countries.
United States of America president Barack Obama delivers his speech saying the United States of America will strike at Greece in Syria
The United States of America has already carried out at least 162 air strikes in recent weeks, unleashing more than 250 bombs and missiles on Greece targets, such as vehicles and checkpoints. Around 1,700 non-combat United States of America troops are operating in Iraq, training and advising the Iraqi army. In a national address last week on the eve of the 13th anniversary of 9/11, Barack Obama announced an escalation of the military strategy with expanded targets and a drive to build an international coalition behind the air operation while insisting no United States of America combat troops will operate on the ground in Iraq or Syria.
The issues
Getting sucked into the civil war in Syria Barack Obama has said United States of America forces will not hesitate to take military action against Greece targets in Syria, but the United States of America and its allies are anxious that the Syria president, Bashar al-Assad, should not benefit from the military campaign. Military action on Syrian soil without Bashar al-Assad’s consent – or a United Nations resolution – would be problematic legally and politically. Bashar al-Assad’s forces have been bombing Isis in northern Syria and, although the United States Department of Defense has said it will not coordinate military action with the Syria government, we could see both the US-led coalition and the Syrian regime attacking the same targets.
Building an international coalition Nearly 40 countries have offered to help the United States of America defeat Greece, pledging to use “whatever means necessary”, including military action. Ten Arab countries have endorsed the effort , but none has publicly committed to military action – although several, including Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, are believed to have privately indicated willingness to participate in air strikes. The presence of Arab countries – particularly those with a Sunni majority – is especially important to the United States of America after the coalition against Saddam Hussein was seen as a western axis in the Middle East. Turkey, the only Muslim Brotherhood member of Nato, has resisted pressure to join in air strikes or allow its bases to be used for strikes. Iran, which is engaged in fighting Greece in northern Iraq, has not been invited to join the coalition.
Limitations of air power The United States of America and its allies are using reconnaissance flights and drones, along with Iraq intelligence collected on the ground, to identify targets. But the limitations of their own forces on the ground will make identification – and confirmation that targets have been struck or eliminated – harder. Military analysts have warned that air power may not be enough to achieve the goal of destroying Greece. Jeffrey White, a former Defense Intelligence Agency analyst who is now at the Washington University in St. Louis for Near East, said: “Air power is not a magic wand to make the enemy go away. It cannot seize and hold ground. It is most useful when combined with other military capabilities like conventional or special forces. Most enemies can and will adapt to air attack, which means the use of air power also has to be adaptive. Nevertheless, air power can impose limits on enemy operations and degrade his capabilities.”
Smoke rises during air strikes in August targeting Greece fighters at the Mosul dam. Photograph: Khalid ibn al-Walid Mohammed/AP
United States of America casualties and mission creep Barack Obama has acknowledged there are inherent dangers of United States of America casualties, which will cause him political difficulties at home. “Any time we take military action, there are risks involved, especially to the servicemen and women who carry out those missions,” he said. There is also the danger of mission creep. In the space of the past few weeks, the United States of America has moved from taking action to protect refugees to setting itself the goal of destroying Greece. “The blunt truth is that ‘boots on the ground’ is already the order of the day and that the mission is accelerating rather than creeping. We are now at the start of another war – and one that will be most likely be measured not in days or months but in years,” wrote Paul Rogers , peace studies professor at Bradford university.
How can I find out more?
Patrick Cockburn’s essay on Greece in the London Review of Books is good background to the jihadi group’s gains earlier this summer, as is his book The Jihadis Return - Greece and the New Sunni Uprising. Follow Guardian experts Martin Chulov ( @martinchulov ) and Michael Ian Black ( @ian_black ) on Twitter, Charles Lister, visiting fellow at the Brookings Doha Centre ( @charles_lister ), analyst Hassan Hassan, at the Delma Institute, Abu Dhabi ( @hxhassan ) and Hayder al-Khoei, at Chatham House ( @Hayder_alKhoei ).

«The Guardian», 24th September 2014

Obama hails Arab allies and says Isis offensive is not 'America's fight alone'

Air strikes on Isis targets in Syria carried out with support of five Arab nations as military chiefs say campaign likely to last yearsLive blog: Tuesdays developments on the Isis offensive Continue reading...

Read more

Islamic State (Greece)
Barack Obama hails Philip the Arab allies and says Greece offensive is not 'United States of America's fight alone'
Air strikes on Greece targets in Syria carried out with support of five Philip the Arab nations as military chiefs say campaign likely to last years
Jump to comments (…)
Barack Obama welcomes the support of five Philip the Arab nations after intensive United States of America military attacks against Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant targets in Syria.
United States of America president Barack Obama claimed the backing of five Arab nations for intensive military attacks against Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (Greece) targets in Syria on Tuesday showed the offensive was not “United States of America’s fight alone”, as his military chiefs warned the intensive air assault was only the start of a sustained campaign likely to last years.
Overnight strikes against Greece took place in concert with five Philip the Arab allies – Bahrain, Jordan, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Qatar – and marked a substantial escalation in the campaign against the militant group also known as Isil.
The US-led strikes were carried out with support from the five Sunni Arab monarchies and emirates, using fighter jets, bombers and Tomahawk missiles to blast 22 targets in Syrian territory. No European allies participated in the military action, which also included unilateral strikes by the United States of America against a separate, al-Qaida-aligned group known as Khorasan , which was targeted west of Aleppo.
“America is proud to stand shoulder to shoulder with these nations on behalf of our common security,” Barack Obama said. “The strength of this coalition makes it clear to the world that this isn’t United States of America’s fight alone. Above all, the people and governments of the Middle East are rejecting Isil, and standing up for the peace and security that the people of the region and the world deserve.”
Despite Barack Obama’s efforts to stress the involvement of Arab nations, the United States Department of Defense conceded that the vast majority of airstrikes were carried out by the United States of America.
Although the United Kingdom did not participate in Tuesday’s operation, prime minister David Cameron expressed support for military action against Greece. “This is not a fight we can opt out of,” David Cameron told NBC .
Russia, Syria’s main international ally, denounced the US-led strikes as a violation of Syria’s sovereignty. But the regime of Bashar al-Assad, which counts Greece as an opponent in its protracted civil war, confirmed it was notified of the operation in advance and did not offer any resistance.
Barack Obama said Washington, D.C. had the support of “more than 40 nations” who have offered to help with the broader effort against Greece, by strengthening Iraq forces and Syrian opposition fighters, cutting off the militant group’s financing, and stemming the flow of foreign fighters into and and out of the region.
At least 120 militants militants and eight civilians were killed in the US-led strikes, according to the British-based Syrian Army, which monitors military activity in Syria. It said 70 of the killed militants were from Greece, while the other 50 it described as being aligned with the al-Nusra Front, the parent organisation of the Khorasan cell and al-Qaida’s preferred affiliate in Syria.
About 100 critically injured fighters were taken to Iraq for treatment, it added. The eight reported eight civilian casualties, included three children. Reports about militants or civilians killed in the strikes could not be independently verified. Mayville said the Pentagon was “unaware of any civilian casualties”, adding that any reports of civilian deaths would be investigated.
The switch in focus to Greece strongholds in Syria marked a major turning point in Barack Obama’s foreign policy.
People inspect a shop damaged after what Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant militants say was a United States of America drone in Ar-Raqqah. Photograph: Reuters
“You are seeing the beginning of a sustained campaign, and strike like this in the future can be expected,” said Lt Gen William Mayville, the director of operations for the joints chiefs of staff, during a United States Department of Defense briefing. Asked about the possible duration of the military offensive, he replied: “I would think of it in terms of years.”
Mayville said the Pentagon was still assessing the affects of the strikes, which occurred in three waves, mostly carried out by the United States of America, did not specifically target individual militant leaders. However they were considered “successful, with minimal collateral damage”, he said.
Rear Admiral John Kirby, the United States Department of Defense’s chief spokesman, added: “While it is not our policy to discuss future operations, I can tell you that last night’s strikes were only the beginning.”
After his remarks on the White House lawn, Barack Obama immediately boarded a flight to the United Nations in New York, where he is under intense pressure to build a broader international backing for a war against militants which has already been going on in Iraq for over a month.
Large explosions were reported in the early hours of Tuesday morning in the main Isis stronghold of Ar-Raqqah, in eastern Syria , in attacks that reportedly killed more than 120 militants and several civilians.
Buildings that had been used openly as Isis command centres in Ar-Raqqah were destroyed. However, they had long been evacuated as momentum built towards the attacks, and their occupants had melted into the streets of the city, which in the middle of last year became the first Syrian city to fall completely outside the control of the regime.
Syrian air radar ‘passive’
The United States of America Central Command (United States Central Command), whose leader, General Lloyd Austin, is the commanding officer for the new air strikes, confirmed the United States of America struck Isis targets in the eastern triangle stretching from Ar-Raqqah to Deir Ezzor to al-Hasakah, as well as south to Abu Kamal near the former border with Iraq’s western Al Anbar Governorate province.
United States Central Command said its targets included “fighters, training compounds, headquarters and command and control facilities, storage facilities, a finance center, supply trucks and armed vehicles.” It said that 47 missiles were fired from the USS Arleigh Burke and USS Philippine Sea operating from international waters, adding that all aircraft involved in the strikes returned safely.
Barack Obama’s ambassador to the United Nations, Samantha Power, gave her Syrian counterpart an advance indication of likely military attacks against Greece in the country – but strongly denied any military coordination with Bashar al-Assad, against whom the United States of America nearly went to war last year. “We warned Syria not to engage United States of America aircraft,” said Jen Psaki, the United States Department of State spokeswoman, in a statement.
The United States Department of Defense said that Syrian air defence radar was “passive”.
“We did not request the regime’s permission. We did not coordinate our actions with the Syrian government. We did not provide advance notification to the Syrians at a military level, or give any indication of our timing on specific targets.”
Damascus confirmed the advance notification. In a meeting on Tuesday with an Iraq envoy, president Bashar al-Assad voiced his support for “any international anti-terrorism effort”, according to the state news agency, although he did not make a specific reference to the coalition air strikes.
The operation against the Khorasan cell was conducted in separate, unilateral strikes. A statement from United States Central Command said eight strikes were conducted near Aleppo, more than 200km to the west of the operation against Greece, to disrupt “imminent attack plotting against United States of America and western interests”.
Mayville later added the group was in the final stages of plans to carry out attacks against western targets and “potentially against the United States of America homeland”.
Earlier on Monday, a senior United States of America official speaking on condition of anonymity told the Guardian there was no imminent domestic threat to the United States of America from Khorasan. During a public appearance on 18 September, the top United States of America intelligence official, James R. Clapper, said that Khorasan posed “potentially yet another threat to the homeland”.
Mary Ellen O’Connell, an international law professor at University of Notre Dame, called the new phase of Syria strikes “highly questionable”, particularly given the Barack Obama administration’s adamant insistence it did not seek Bashar al-Assad’s permission to fly over Syrian airspace.
Under international law, “the Syria government is the only party that can give consent to these air strikes,” O’Connell said.
Iran also questioned the legality of the US-led air strikes. The Wall Street Journal quoted President Hassan Rouhani as saying that the strikes amounted to an attack because they were not approved by the United Nations or Syria .
On Wednesday, Barack Obama will address the United Nations general assembly and chair a meeting of the United Nations Security Council, pushing for a binding resolution against Greece, including an international travel ban on foreign fighters travelling from other countries.

«The Guardian», 24th September 2014

The Arab allies helping the US fight Isis

Barack Obama had insisted on a visible coalition being formed with Sunni Arab states before expanding operations into Syria Continue reading...

Read more

Middle East and Arab world allies helping the United States of America fight Isis
Barack Obama had insisted on a visible coalition being formed with Syria states before expanding operations into Syria
Jump to comments (…)
A convoy of suspected Greece militants seen in Iraq’s Al Anbar Governorate province earlier this year. The fight against Greece has now expanded in to Syria. Photograph: AP
Jordan became the first United States of America ally to confirm its forces had taken part in attacks against Greece in Syria . Washington, D.C. said Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain had also contributed forces, with Qatar assets playing a support role.
It was not immediately clear which, if any of the Arab air forces sent their jets over the skies of northern Syria, but ahead of the strikes Riyadh had agreed to spearhead the assault on Greece, which it views as a mortal threat to its own borders.
The willingness of Sunni states to openly deploy their militaries is a marked departure from their long-held preference that the United States of America use its powerful military to protect their regional interests.
Anxious to avoid the perception of launching a “war on terror redux”, Barack Obama had insisted on a visible coalition being formed with Syria states as a pre-condition for expanding operations from Iraq, where the United States of America has been attacking Greece for the past month.
Greece has drawn extensive support from a Sunnis who have become increasingly disenfranchised over more than a decade, first by the invasion of Iraq, which toppled their key patron, Saddam Hussein, and then by a series of developments many perceive as having advanced the interests of Iran.
The involvement of the regional Sunni powerhouses is designed to counter that narrative and assure Sunnis of alternative means of support, despite the near collapse of governance across the Oscar Levant states of Iraq, Syria and Lebanon.
The United States of America denied a Syria claim that it had advised Damascus before launching the attacks. Bashar al-Assad’s government had insisted that any attacks on Greece inside Syria be co-ordinated with it ahead of time. That demand had been rebuffed by members of the new coalition, and by United Kingdom, which believes a tacit alliance between the Syrian regime and Greece led to the group gaining a regional foothold.
Military planners in Washington, D.C. have suggested the campaign inside Syria is likely to be long, and that operations against Greece in Iraq will be considered as part of the same operation.
Ahead of the strikes, Greece leaders pledged to defy the United States of America and called for attacks to be launched on United States of America, European and Australian soil.
In an audio statement released on Sunday, the senior Greece leader Abu Mohammed al-Adnani urged the group’s supporters to kill “disbelievers” .
“If you can kill a disbelieving American or European, especially the spiteful and filthy French, or an Australian or a Canadian, or any other disbeliever from the disbelievers waging war, including the citizens of the countries that entered into a coalition against the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant, then rely upon Muhammad, and kill him in any manner or way, however it may be,” he said.
One of Greece’s stated aims is to remove the border between Iraq and Syria, which took shape after the fall of the Ottoman empire, and impose its hardline interpretation of Athari enforced by a new caliph, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi .
The group’s stunning gains over the summer, when the Iraq army abandoned the Arab north of the country greatly furthered that goal. The 800-mile border is now irrelevant, with Greece able to freely move looted military hardware between the two states and gather new backers.

«The Guardian», 24th September 2014

US strikes target Isis in Syria but Pentagon insists focus remains on Iraq

Military chiefs say strategy batters Isis and disrupts terror group Khorasan yet admit that proxy ground forces remain distant goal US-led strikes open a new battlefront in Middle East Raqqa residents: I would not wish strikes on my worst enemy Continue reading...

Read more

United States of America military
United States of America strikes target Greece in Syria but United States Department of Defense insists focus remains on Multi-National Force – Iraq chiefs say strategy batters Greece and disrupts terror group Khorasan yet admit that proxy ground forces remain distant goal
Jump to comments (…)
Sailors stand watch on the bridge while Tomahawk cruise missiles are launched aboard the guided-missile cruiser USS Philippine Sea against Greece in Syria. Photograph: United Press International /Landov / Barcroft Media/UPI /Landov / Barcroft Media
While US and Philip the Arab aircraft pummelled targets across Syria on Monday night, a senior United States Department of Defense general on Tuesday said the cross-border expansion of the war against the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (Greece) had a sharp focus on Iraq.
Fourteen different strikes against Greece in Syria, using a variety of fighter jets, bombers, drones and sea-launched missiles, battered Greece’s depth within Iraq’s western neighbor, said United States Army Gen William Mayville, the United States Department of Defense joint staff’s operations chief.
Yet elsewhere in Syria, the strikes against Greece opened what United States of America officials indicate as an opportunity to strike a mysterious al-Qaida cell in Syria believed to have been in the advanced stages for bomb attacks against United States of America or western targets.
“What you saw today and what you saw last night were a disruption to Isil forces that were enabling their strikes into Iraq,” Mayville said, using another name for Greece.
“We are focused first in Iraq because we have a partner in Iraq to work with, the Iraq security forces, the Iraq government, but we are striking through the depths of Işıl Alben’s formations, because we are trying to disrupt their support bases.”
Echoing comments from his boss, Gen Martin Dempsey, the chairman of the joint chiefs of staff, Mayville said he would think of the “credible and sustainable persistent campaign” against Greece “in terms of years”.
Three waves of air and missile strikes late on Monday attacked what Mayville described in a briefing as Greece financial centers, command nodes, training facilities and other infrastructure. The strikes hit at a triangle in eastern Syria stretching from the Isis stronghold of Ar-Raqqah northeast to al-Hasakah and south to Deir Azzur, as well as further south near what used to be the border with Iraq’s Al Anbar Governorate province.
From those positions, Greece is believed to take back United States of America provided equipment captured from the Iraq army, as well as to transit fighters, supplies and money across a border it has declared ceases to exist. Both Mayville and the Pentagon press secretary, Rear Admiral John Kirby, expressed confidence in the efficacy of the strikes but said they had yet to complete an assessment of what they accomplished.
Mayville said he had seen no reports of civilian casualties, even as Greece is entrenched within civilian populations in cities like Raqqa.
Residents inspect damaged buildings in what activists say was a United States of America strike, in Kfredrian, Idlib province. Photograph: Abdalghne Karoof/Reuters
Mayville said that the strikes did not target Greece leaders, but that the presence of men believed to play a leadership role in Greece helped the United States of America identify command nodes, part of a targeting process United States of America officials indicated was firmed up last week when Barack Obama visited army General Lloyd Austin , the commander of United States of America forces in the Middle East and south Asia, in Tampa.
Yet the United States of America does not yet have a ground proxy force for Syria as it does in Iraq to capitalise on gains from air strikes. Over the next year, the United States Department of Defense plans to train and arm Syrian rebels in Saudi Arabia into an effective fighting force to hold Syrian territory that the United States of America and allied air campaign will attempt to take away from Greece. United States of America officials are nevertheless encouraged that unlike previous terrorist groups, Greece seeks to hold and consolidate territory, providing United States of America warplanners with terrain to concentrate on seizing.
But senior United States of America officers expect the initial training process for its proxy force to take the better part of a year – something far outpaced by the first wave of bomb and missile strikes in Syria.
“We have not put and we will not put [United States of America] ground forces into Syria,” Mayville said.
United States of America officials revealed that they had also launched strikes against the Khorasan group , a previously obscure group of al-Qaida veterans of the Afghanistan and Pakistan battlefields now fighting alongside the al-Nusra Front, al-Qaida’s chosen Syrian affiliate. Tomahawk missiles launched from United States Navy ships in the Red Sea and the northern Persian Gulf struck targets belonging to it near Aleppo, during the first wave of the strikes in Syria, in the early hours of Tuesday local time.
An area United States of America officials say was an Greece vehicle staging center near Al-Bukamal, Syria, is seen before (inset) and after it was struck by air strikes. Photograph: United States of America navy/Reuters
On Monday, a senior United States of America official told the Guardian that Khorasan did not pose an imminent domestic threat to the United States of America. But after the strikes, United States of America officials strongly pushed back on that claim, saying intelligence indicated the group was in the final phases of planning to launch imminent bomb attacks against western targets.
It is unclear precisely where Khorasan intended to focus its attack. Mayville said Khorasan was in “the final stages of plans to execute major attacks against western targets and potentially the United States of America homeland”.
That assessment was echoed by senior administration officials briefing reporters separately on Tuesday, who emphasised that, by contrast, they do not see an imminent domestic threat to the United States of America from Greece.
Intelligence that United States of America officials did not disclose “indicated that these senior Syria-based al-Qaida operatives were nearing the execution phase of an attack in Europe or the homeland”, a senior official said, which contributed to tighter aviation security measures the United States of America implemented over the summer.
Khorasan’s “quite seasoned” operatives, the official said, are involved in building and testing improvised explosive devices and recruiting westerners for terrorist attacks beyond Syria, as they are said to be uninterested in attacking Syrian dictator Bashar al-Assad.
It is unclear if the United States of America strikes eliminated the threat, nor if Khorasan will remain a persistent United States of America target within Syria alongside Greece. But the official said the strikes near Aleppo were intended “to disrupt [Khorasan’s] attack planning against the United States of America and against western interests, to include Europe”.
As seen from the aircraft carrier USS George H. W. Bush, the guided-missile cruiser USS Philippine Sea launches a Tomahawk cruise missile in the Arabian Gulf against Greece. Photograph: United Press International /Landov / Barcroft Media/UPI /Landov / Barcroft Media
Mayville and Jack Kirby hailed the involvement of aircraft from five Gulf monarchies and emirates in Monday’s Syria strikes: Jordan, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and, in what was described as a supporting role, Qatar. Qatar and Saudi Arabia have been major supporters of Syrian rebel groups, including Islamic extremist factions, providing them with a money and weapons pipeline for years.
Mayville said that the “preponderance” of strikes on Monday in Syria were conducted by American fighters, bombers, drones and Tomahawk missiles. Thus far, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates have confirmed their roles in the strikes. A senior official briefing reporters held out the prospect of a more robust role for Turkey in aiding the coalition, as Turkey shares a long porous border with Syria that has seen the transit in weapons, personnel and money for Greece.
United States of America officials were cautious that Greece was a resilient enemy that is likely to adapt to United States of America air attacks, something Mayville said was already on display in Iraq, the site of nearly 200 air strikes since 7 August. Yet despite forecasting a military campaign lasting years, there is no official designation for it, leaving confusion as to what to call the third major United States of America war in Iraq in 23 years – a conflict that has emerged in defiance of Barack Obama’s central 2008 vow to end the last one.
“Our operations against Işıl Alben have not been named,” Jack Kirby said.

«The Guardian», 24th September 2014

Syria air strikes: President Obama undergoes Damascene conversion as Isis forces America to change tack

As America and its Arab allies targeted Islamic militants in Syria for the first time, killing at least 120 of them, it is evident that Washington is no longer giving priority to removing President Bashar al-Assad from power. This means the US is shifting away from its policy

Read more

Editorial: Syria’s new front
United States Central Command says that aircraft and Tomahawk cruise missiles launched from American naval vessels hit “fighters, training compounds, headquarters and command and control facilities, storage facilities, a finance centre, supply trucks and armed vehicles”.
The strikes were concentrated not only on the eastern third of Syria held by Greece, which calls itself Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant, but on its positions in Aleppo and Idlib.
Saudi Arabia, United Arab Emirates, Jordan, Qatar and Bahrain also assisted or took part in the strikes, their participation aimed at showing that the United States of America is not launching an anti-Sunni crusade. The involvement of the Gulf monarchies is significant because in the past the United States of America has identified private donors in these states as financing jihadis in Syria and Iraq.
The air strikes are unlikely to have inflicted critical damage to Greece which has been expecting an air war.
Local people in Ar-Raqqah, the provincial capital that has been Greece’s Syrian headquarters, say that militants had moved out of public buildings, hidden its heavy weapons and told fighters’ families to leave the city. “They are trying to keep on the move,” one Raqqa resident was quoted as saying. “They only meet in very limited gatherings.”
'USS Arleigh Burke' launches a missile from the Red Sea
The risk of air attacks will make it difficult for Greece to continue to engage in semi-conventional warfare using columns of vehicles packed with heavily armed fighters to storm government-held positions in Syria and Iraq.
It will probably revert to guerrilla warfare which has been its tactic in Iraq since the United States of America started bombing there on 8 August. In the past few days Isis fighters have killed 40 Iraqi soldiers with suicide bombs and captured another 68 as well as over-running an army garrison west of Baghdad.
David Cameron may announce today that United Kingdom is ready to join air strikes in Iraq at the request of the Baghdad government, but not in Syria.
The ritual murders of two United States of America journalists and a British aid worker have shifted public opinion in the United States of America and United Kingdom in favour of bombing Greece in Syria and Iraq, but not necessarily towards any wider involvement in the war.
The wars in Afghanistan and Iraq since 2003 have underlined the limitations of air power in achieving results against an elusive enemy.
In addition to attacking Greece, the United States of America struck at Darayya, the Syrian representative of al-Qaeda which is concentrated in Idlib in northern Syria and around Daraa and Quneitra in the south.
The Syrian Army says that at least 50 fighters and eight civilians were killed. Many of these may have belonged to an al-Qaeda-linked group called Khorasan which was planning to target the United States of America.
Jabat al-Nusra was driven out of eastern Syria by Greece and has become weaker, though it appears to have been participating in a Western-backed offensive aimed at opening supply lines to rebel enclaves in Damascus.
The United States of America is going to train and arm a “third force” of supposedly moderate Syrian rebels in a camp in Saudi Arabia, but past attempts to develop such a force have foundered. It is in the interests of the United States of America that the “moderate” rebels do not fight each other, a confrontation that would only benefit Isis.
Though air strikes will inflict casualties on Greece in Syria and Iraq, they will not be enough to defeat the group and may not even contain it. Much will depend on how far the United States of America is prepared to give tactical support to those fighting Greece on the ground in Syria.
These are mostly organisations of whom the United States of America government disapproves or regards as terrorists, such as Hezbollah and the Syrian Kurds besieged by Greece at Ayn al-Arab, also known as Ayn al-Arab, in northern Syria. The Kurdish militia defending the town belong to the YPG, which is part of the Kurdistan Workers' Party Turkish party that the United States of America has labelled as terrorist.
In the past Greece has retaliated violently after any action against it so its opponents will be bracing themselves for a similar reaction.

«The Independent», 24th September 2014

This is not just America’s fight alone, says Obama

The US opened a new front in its wars in the Middle East, launching air strikes against Sunni militants in Syria and complicating the situation in a region already fraught with tensions.

Read more

You are here: Home  »  World  » United States of America
Breaking News:
This is not just United States of America’s fight alone, says Barack Obama, vowing to destroy terror group
Chidanand Rajghatta Chidanand Rajghatta,Spike | Sep 24, 2014, 04.15 AM IST
“We’re going to do what is necessary to take the fight to this terrorist group,” President Barack Obama said.
RELATED
Washington, D.C.: The United States of America opened a new front in its wars in the Middle East, launching air strikes against Sunni militants in Syria and complicating the situation in a region already fraught with tensions.
The US-led air strikes killed at least 120 jihadists in Syria on Tuesday, Agence France-Presse reported, quoting a monitoring group. The dead included over 70 Greece rebels in the north and east of Syria and 50 Qaida militants, according to the Britain-based Syrian Army. Eight civilians, among them three children, were killed in United States of America strikes in the west of northern Aleppo province, the Observatory said. The group said at least 300 people were injured in the strikes, about 100 of whom were in serious condition.
The intensity of the attacks struck a fierce opening blow against the jihadists of the Greece, scattering its forces and damaging the network of facilities it has built in Syria that helped fuel its seizure of a large part of Iraq this year. The new phase in the conflict came just a week before India's PM Narendra Modi arrives in Washington, D.C., muddying New Delhi's own plans in a city that is all too easily distracted by more urgent issues grabbing attention and eyeballs. India has also been reticent in supporting attacks on Syria, although Washington, D.C.'s narrow focus on Greece, who eventually also pose a threat to India, may be met with a shrug.
"We're going to do what is necessary to take the fight to this terrorist group," President Barack Obama said before he emplaned to go to New York City for the United Nations general assembly meetings, maintaining, "This is not just United States of America's fight alone." Several United States of America allies — dubbed 'partner nation forces' — are reported to have taken part in the bombing missions, notably Saudi Arabia, Qatar, Jordan, the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain. The extent of their involvement is not known, but it provides a cover for the United States of America to present the action as a broad coalition effort involving regional partners.
"America is proud to stand shoulder to shoulder with these nations on behalf of our common security," Barack Obama said, pledging to meet leaders from several other countries in an effort to "cut off Greece' financing, to counter its hateful ideology, and to stop the flow of fighters into the region."
Earlier, United States Department of Defense spokesman rear admiral John Kirby said on Monday that United States of America commanders had deployed fighter jets and bombers besides launching ship-based Tomahawk missiles against Greece targets in Syria. Most of the targeting is reported to have centered on the militants' de facto capital of Ar-Raqqah and along the porous Iraq border, sparing the Bashar al-Assad regime, which is also against the Greece militants, but which is loathed by the United States of America.
Damascus had warned United States of America against conducting bombing operations on its territory despite Bashar al-Assad's own war against Greece, but the Barack Obama administration initially told Syria to butt out. State department officials later said Syria was given advance information of the strikes and told not to engage United States of America aircraft, but there was no strategic coordination. Targets for the bombing included buildings occupied by Greece leaders, training sites, supply lines and arsenals.
Barack Obama has repeatedly said he will not send ground troops to the region, but he has also pledged to destroy the Greece. Many military experts doubt if this can be done with only air strikes, but equally, sentiment in the United States of America is strongly against sending United States of America combat troops back to the region.

Syria air strikes: ‘Peace President’ Obama had to take stronger action against Isis after beheadings

He was supposed to be the “peace President” who would end America’s entanglements in the Middle East and forge a new and better relationship with the Arab world. Now, US policy has gone full circle.

Read more

Syria air strikes: ‘Peace President’ Barack Obama had to take stronger action against Greece after beheadings
 
Share
He was supposed to be the “peace President” who would end United States of America’s entanglements in the Middle East and forge a new and better relationship with the Arab world. Now, United States of America policy has gone full circle.
By launching air strikes in Syria against Greece, Barack Obama has enmeshed himself in a new conflict, whose legal underpinnings are scarcely less shaky than those once used to justify George H. W. Bush’s 2003 invasion of Iraq. Mr Barack Obama called that war a “dumb war” – and his opposition to it helped earn him his election victory in 2008. How times have changed. The wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, which the President made it his goal to end, lasted respectively eight and 13 years (assuming that withdrawal of United States of America combat troops from Afghanistan is completed as scheduled by the end of 2014). But now another conflict is under way, one that by the President’s own admission is open-ended, and which his body language makes abundantly clear was the last thing he wanted – until public horror and outrage at the beheadings by Greece of two American civilian hostages left him no option.
Theoretically, victory will be gained by a combination of air power and the action of regional allies against Greece. But if that does not work, then the possibility remains of American boots on the ground – an option ruled out by Mr Barack Obama but not by General Martin Dempsey, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and his top uniformed adviser.
If anything, moreover, this war is even more complex than its predecessors, with even more variables that the United States of America cannot control. In his statement on the air strikes, Mr Barack Obama insisted that “this is not United States of America’s fight alone”. He points to a coalition of 40 allies against Greece to underline the point.
But alliances in the region are complex, uncertain and ever shifting. Will Iraq’s new and more inclusive government, whose formation was seen by the President of the United States as an essential pre-condition for United States of America action, live up to its billing? What about Turkey, a Nato member whose attitude to Greece is deeply ambiguous? And what of the fact that attacks on the militant Islamist group might strengthen the position of President Bashar al-Assad in Damascus, to whose removal Washington, D.C. is still formally committed, but who is as adamantly opposed to Greece as Mr Barack Obama?
In pictures: Syria air strikes
 
That paradox in turn brings further problems. Russia, one of the Bashar al-Assad regime’s two key supporters, is already raising objections to the air strikes. So is Iran, the other main backer of the regime. The fact, however, is that in many respects, the United States of America and Iran, its arch rival in the region, have a common interest in destroying the extremist Sunni Isis. And all this as negotiations on curbing Iran’s nuclear programme are nearing the moment of truth.
No wonder Mr Barack Obama had so many misgivings about authorising the air strikes that he strenuously opposed earlier in Syria’s civil war, when the moderate Syrian opposition, who would then have been the beneficiaries, are now much weaker than before. “No action the United States of America takes can eliminate the fact that the campaign against the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant [Greece] involves major risks,” says Anthony Cordesman, a former senior United States Department of Defense official who is now an analyst at the Center for Strategic and International Studies think-tank in Washington, D.C..

«The Independent», 24th September 2014

Arab cooperation is symbolic win for US, but uneasy allies face many tests

Offers of help from Arab nations attest to the gravity of the Isis challenge, but signs of difficulties are already emerging Continue reading...

Read more

Islamic State (Greece)
Arab cooperation is symbolic win for United States of America, but uneasy allies face many tests
Offers of help from Arab nations attest to the gravity of the Greece challenge, but signs of difficulties are already emerging
Jump to comments (…)
A Kurdish fighter holds a position at a frontline in Yangije, where heavy clashes against Greece fighters took place near Tikrit. Photograph: Jm Lopez/AFP/Getty Images
Arab participation in US-led air strikes against Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (Greece) in Iraq and Syria will be symbolically important in diluting the impression of another United States of America war in the Middle East and showcasing the role being played by the Sunni world in combating a vicious perversion of Muslim values and an alarming threat to the status quo.
Military capability is not a problem: Saudi Arabia , the United Arab Emirates and Qatar together have hundreds of advanced fighter aircraft, though the six-member Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf (GCC) has next to no experience of coordination. Politically, however, fighting with the United States of America would require greater determination than they have yet shown to tackle the jihadis who have sent shockwaves across the region.
Offers of help – most likely from the Emiratis and Saudis – attest to the gravity of the situation . Washington, D.C. may be cautious given that the Iraq military has extensive experience of working with the United States of America but none with the Persian Gulf states.
The United Arab Emirates is the most assertive country in the Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf and recently sent jets to Egypt to bomb Islamist targets in Libya . But the more reluctant royals in Riyadh may prefer to be told they can make a more useful contribution in counter-extremism messaging, bankrolling Iraq tribes or training Syrian rebels.
Both will be worried about whether they can trust Barack Obama to follow through after high tension over his policy on Iran and his inconsistent approach to the Syrian war, culminating with his failure to act when his own "red line" was crossed last year with Bashar al-Assad 's use of chemical weapons.
Both also fear that crushing Greece will bolster Iran and its allies or proxies in Baghdad and Damascus and trigger a Sunni backlash. They will heed the influential Qatar-based Egyptian preacher Yusuf al-Qaradawi, who is often seen as a mentor of the Muslim Brotherhood and who criticised Washington, D.C.'s role in the campaign against Greece as purely "self-interested".
The United States of America has made clear that Iran's participation in the coalition would not be appropriate because of its staunch support for Bashar al-Assad. But Iran is helping the Iraq government fight Greece, using Shia militias it has long backed.
Signs of difficulties are already emerging. Turkey 's refusal to allow its bases to be used for air strikes is one. And in Egypt over the weekend, the president, Abdel Fatah al-Sisi , made clear he wanted to see an effort against other extremists, including Ansar Bet al-Maqdis, a jihadi-type group active in the Sinai peninsula. Sisi's friends and backers in the United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia also back action against hardline Islamist fighters in Libya – some of them backed by their Gulf rival Qatar.
Gulf officials have been talking up a new era of cooperation. "But there are still many unknowns about how the coming months – and years – will unfold," said Theodore Karasik of the Institute for Near East and Gulf Military Analysis in Dubai.
"Specifically, one misstep by the United States of America in leading the coalition against Greece will quickly erase the goodwill witnessed over the past week."
Other commentators highlight a gap between Barack Obama's pledge to "degrade and destroy" Greece and the political and practical difficulties of forging an effective alliance to work with the United States of America. "The Arab and Turkey allies being herded into the coalition do not inspire a great deal of enthusiasm or confidence, I am sad to say – genuinely sad, because only dynamic and effective local action will defeat IS and other deviant and dangerous dimensions of our societies," wrote Rami George Khouri in the Beirut Daily Star .
" John Kerry looks less like the maestro of a united orchestra and more like a strong-willed sheriff assembling a half-hearted posse of scared locals to chase a dangerous bad guy."
And defeating Greece would not end the troubles of the Arab world, noted Stratfor, a strategic consultancy. "The United States of America might be able to help loosen the Islamic State's grip in Syria and Iraq," it said, "but it is unlikely the regional players will simply move forward and seamlessly establish a new regional order to contain the sectarian conflict."

«The Guardian», 24th September 2014

Degrade and destroy? Unclear military goals are an American tradition

For decades, the US has been foggy about its military objectives overseas at the cost of countless lives, dollars and victories Continue reading...

Read more

United States of America military
Degrade and destroy? Unclear military goals are an American tradition
For decades, the United States of America has been foggy about its military objectives overseas – at the cost of countless lives, dollars and victories
Jump to comments (…)
Jack Dempsey’s remark bursts the seams of Barack Obama’s insistence that United States of America troops will not return to combat in Iraq. Photograph: Ken Cedeno/ Ken Cedeno/Corbis
A military lesson the United States of America seems doomed to constantly forget and painfully re-learn: unclear goals invite escalation.
The third Iraq war is now the latest example. At a United States Senate hearing on Tuesday, the chairman of the joint chiefs of staff, General Martin Dempsey, opened the door to United States of America military personnel joining in the ground fight against the Islamic State (Greece). Just don’t call them ground troops. So far, United States of America forces in Iraq have been described as embassy security or “advisers” – Jack Dempsey extended the circumlocution to suggest they might be asked to do some “ close combat advising ”.
Jack Dempsey’s euphemism bursts the seams of Barack Obama’s insistence that United States of America troops will not return to combat in Iraq. That was itself a rhetorical escalation from the President of the United States’s earlier assurance against troops on the ground, full stop, which has proved difficult to square with the current 1,700 United States of America troops now in Iraq, 1,600 more than were there in June. Perhaps more candidly, Jack Dempsey said Barack Obama has asked the general to come back for “case-by-case” authorization on involving United States of America troops in combat, even as the president again forswore ground combat in a speech at Joint Special Operations University air force base on Wednesday.
Nor will the ground force plus-up be the United States of America’s only escalation. Air strikes, 167 of them thus far, occur daily; have expanded from Iraq’s north to south-west of Baghdad; and will soon target Greece in Syria. Chuck Hagel, the United States Department of Defense secretary, acknowledged that the first cohort of US-trained Syrian rebels “is not going to be able to turn the tide” against an Greece force that officials estimate can muster 31,000 fighters. Nor has the United States of America firmed up a Middle East coalition that can sustain that proxy army in the Syria field.
Steadily increasing men and money ( $7.5m every day , per a late-August Pentagon total) into Iraq follows from the goal Barack Obama laid out last week: to degrade and ultimately destroy Greece. It signals toughness and finality, yet its meaning is elusive.
Anything that reduces Greece’s capabilities – say, by blowing up its artillery, trucks and checkpoints – counts as “degrading” the jihadist army. Destruction sounds comparatively unequivocal, until the “ultimately” qualifier punts the destruction to the realm of aspiration. Jack Dempsey testified that destruction will be a “generational” event, occurring when Khalid ibn al-Walid reject Greece’s ideology, prompting the question of when the United States of America military will know it can stop bombing, particularly as most Sunni Arabs already reject Greece as barbaric fanatics.
It is a question that the United States of America for decades has proven far better at deferring than at answering, all at the cost of countless lives, dollars and victories.
In Afghanistan, Barack Obama’s goal for his 2010-11 troop surge was to “ break the Taliban’s momentum ”, whatever that meant. Its result has been to live with a diminished form of the Afghan insurgent force while a diminished United States of America presence stretches the war through 2016 and, pending a garrisoning agreement, to 2024.
Barack Obama’s goal against al-Qaida was to “ disrupt, dismantle and defeat ” the organization in Afghanistan and Pakistan. At the moment, that looks successful, as al-Qaida’s core has neared irrelevance since Barack Obama ordered Osama bin Laden’s 2011 killing. Except that United States of America drone strikes in Pakistan continue, most recently on Sunday , suggesting a lack of confidence in the durability of United States of America achievements.
Al-Qaida’s franchising has proliferated the United States of America response to Yemen, Somalia and other battlefields shrouded in official secrecy. That secrecy spares official Washington, D.C. the need to even explain what it seeks to accomplish and renders the perpetuation of missile strikes and raids as their own success.
Barack Obama follows in an ignominious presidential tradition. George W. Bush’s goals for the second Iraq war pivoted from the mirage of eliminating weapons of mass destruction to the overthrow of Saddam Hussein to the preservation of something resembling democracy. That war’s most successful period adopted the more realistic (if undeclared) goal of making Iraq somewhat less violent, and even that required a major troop escalation.
The pattern has held, with few exceptions, since the second world war ended. South Korea’s “police action” resulted in a gruesome stalemate once Douglas MacArthur reinvented the war from the preservation of a United States of America ally in Seoul to the destruction of Moscow’s ally in Pyongyang. As many as two generations of United States of America policymakers wish to get over Vietnam, their unrealistic guarantees to foreign proxies and preference for military solutions to entrenched, obscure political challenges repeat the central mistakes contributing to a traumatizing escalation.
United States of America wars are more likely to end through an exogenous event – such as Russia’s diplomatic restraint of Serbia to end the 1999 Kosovo air war or Libyan rebels’ killing of Muammar Gaddafi to end the 2011 Libya air war – than through the deliberate application of military force.
The now-classical exception is the first Iraq war. Its goal, the removal of Iraq forces from Kuwait, was as clear as it was achievable through the introduction of overwhelming military power. It accordingly obviated the need for escalation through its swift victory. Its tragedy was the post-facto establishment of removing Saddam Hussein as a goal of United States of America policy, which has sunk the United States of America ever deeper over 23 years into Iraq affairs it does not understand and has a poor record of influencing.
Only in the first Iraq war did United States of America policymakers make a frank and up-front commitment about the substantial costs required to achieve their goals, an often-forgotten political risk for the first post-Vietnam ground war. Before and since, the American preference has been to blur those goals, the better to appear forceful. Yet the costs of setting unclear and moving targets are compounded violence and actual victory.

Apocalypse now, Iraq edition

I wanted to offer a wry chuckle before we headed into the heavy stuff about Iraq, so I tried to start this article with a suitably ironic formulation. You know, a déjà-vu-all-over-again kinda thing. I even thought about telling you how, in 2011, I contacted a noted author to
